unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Computer Chips
question_text:
Suppose $10$ computer chips are randomly selected for a very large population.
If $95\%$ of the chips work effectively, what is the probability of getting zero defective chips out of the $10$ chosen?
solution:
Since the chips are from a large population, this situation is close to being independent, so the probabilities can be multiplied because running the operation "without replacement" has no effect on the individual probabilities with each successive check.

$$0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95 \cdot 0.95$$

$$\text{OR simply: }(0.95)^{10} = 0.5987$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'A'.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect. The probability of $0.95$ refers to simply the probability of a single chip NOT being defective.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. The probability of $0.05$ refers to simply the probability of a single chip being defective.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. The probability of $0.000976$ refers to zero NON-defective chips of the $10$ chosen ($0.5^{10}$).

Choice 'E' is incorrect. The probability of $0.4283$ the compliment of zero defective chips chosen out of $10$.
